newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: PRESS DIGEST - New Zealand newspapers - Jan 30.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New Zealand newspapers - Jan 30.

text.p: THE DOMINION

A security guard usually stationed outside Trust Bank's Naenae branch was not working when a bank teller, described as a "gentle giant", was slain during a bungled robbery on Wednesday, witnesses said. William Brown, married with two daughters, was apparently shot in the back of the head while making a telephone call from the Everest Ave bank about 10.20 a.m. Brown's wife, Nadia, said on Wednesday night that his mother used to call her 1.85-metre (6ft 1in) son "her gentle giant" because he was such a kind man. Police on Wednedsay identified only one offender but a witness said three men were involved. Page 1.

Rifts within the Alliance revealed by a leaked memo sent by Greens co-leader Jeanette Fitzsimons had now been dealt with, Fitzsimons said on Wednesday. In the January 22 memo, Fitzsimons threatened to resign as Alliance deputy if she was again excluded from decision making. However, on Wednesday Fitzsimons said her concerns were addressed at Tuesday's Alliance caucus meeting. She had also spoken to Alliance leader Jim Anderton, who had taken her concerns seriously. Page 2.

The parliamentary year is set to start with an acrimonious debate over select committee memberships and chairmanships. There had been an expectation the memberships and chairmanships would be resolved by deals before the resumption of Parliament on February 18. But National senior whip John Carter said that till parliament began sitting nothing could be certain.

Labour Leader Helen Clark called for a public inquiry into Aotearoa Television Network, the Auckland television station granted $4 million of public money earier this week to stay afloat till June. Her call followed a television report about
changes in the company name and links with former employees of European Pacific, the company at the centre of the commission of inquiry into Cook Island tax affairs. Page 2.

A survey of primary schools in Auckland confirmed teacher supply in the region was well under control, Education Minister Wyatt Creech said yesterday. "As far as can be ascertained, every primary school class in Auckland has a trained and qualified teacher," Creech said. Responses from 369 schools showed only 15 had classes they had been unable to staff and each position had been filled, with Education Ministry help, he
said. Page 2.

Associate Health Minister Neil Kirton wants special teams to assess the health of children in "at risk" communities when they start school. The NZ First MP said on Wednesday that providing free health care for children under five, as promised in his party's coalition agreement with National, was a step in the right direction. But that might not be enough to improve the health of all children. In some cases parents did not take their child to the doctor until it was too late. Page 2.

The New Zealand dollar fell to its lowest level in five and a half months against the United States dollar on Wednesday, bringing some hope to struggling exporters. The Kiwi dollar was down a third of a cent to just under US 69 cents on Wednesday. Manufacturers Federation spokesman Gilbert Peterson said the fall from about US71c earlier this month to US68.8c on Wednesday would make a big difference to the confidence of exporters. Page 12.

United States-based investment bank Goldman Sachs and Co said on Wednesday the rapid rise of the New Zealand dollar that began last year "may be over". "After being wrong in 1996 about an early reversal of Kiwi over-valuation, we are cautiously adopting a negative stance toward the currency," Goldman Sachs says in its weekly analyst report. "There is certainly nothing attractive about the Kiwi." Page 12

AMP subsidiary Ergo has dropped its floating mortgage rate to 9.4 percent -- the lowest level for almost two years and setting a new benchmark for loan rates. Almost all other main banks have floating martgage rates at 9.95 percent, with HongkongBank at 9.75 percent. Ergo has dropped its floating rate from 9.9 percent and the fall means a saving of $52 a months on a typical mortgage of $150,000. Page 12.

Telecom said yesterday it was cutting 122 staff immediately from its Australian subsidiary Pacific Star Communications as part of its loss-making Pacific Star businesses. The assets of Pacific Star Communications are to be sold. Telecom owns 51 percent of Pacific Star Communications, and Telecom shareholder Bell Atlantic the other 49 percent. "We are basically looking at selling the assets of Pacific Star Communications," John Bell, Telecom general manager of business development, said. Page 12.

Macraes Mining Company achieved record gold output, cash margin and unaudited profit before tax both in the three months and the full year to December, the miner said on Wednesday. Unaudited annual profit before tax jumped to $23 million, more than double last year's audited $11.35 million and "substantially ahead of budget", it told the Stock Exchange. Gold production was up at 138,464 ounces for the year, from 116,365 previously. The operating margin rose to $299 an ounce, from $239 an ounce for 1995, as cash cost eased to $402 an ounce an ounce from $470 an ounce. Page 12.

Australia's Just Jeans' 35.5 cent share bid for listed Underground Fashions has been recommended to its 350 minority shareholders by an independent director. "While shareholders should form their own view on whether or not to accept the offer, I will be accepting the offer for all the shares beneficially held by me, and I recommend that minority shareholders should also accept," independent director Stuart Cairns said. Page 12.

-- A $20 million float of a South Island deer farming company is planned for March. Businessman Phil Pryke confirmed he would be chairman of New Zealand Deer Farms, which will use the money raised to buy deer farms and stock. The company is owned by interests associated with Tasman Agriculture founder Howard Paterson. Page 12.

More rationalisation will be needed in electricity retailing before power companies can significantly lift their financial performance, a study of returns by Ernst and Young says. Electric power companies have improved their efficiency, cutting

average line charges a unit of electricity delivered by three percent between March 1995 and March 1996, the study says. But while efficiency gains caused direct and indirect cost measures to fall by 11 percent and 18 percent respectively, the opportunity for dramatic cost savings still exists in a number of large companies, the study says. Page 12.
THE NEW ZEALAND HERALD

Nardia Brown bought a special watch at Sydney airport last month for husband Bill's 50th birthday this November. On Wednesday night, stunned and shaken as she was trying to come to terms with his horrific death in a Lower Hutt bank robbery, she wondered what had made her insist that he wore it immediately. "It's as though I knew. It was a fantastic watch and I wanted to see it on him so I said, 'Wear it now. Don't wait'. I'm glad now he did because now he never will ... ever." The quiet, unassuming bank teller, father of two adult daughters, was shot in the head during the holdup of Naenae branch of Trust Bank.

The $4 million extra government funding for Aotearoa Television Network is on hold after revelations of a link between the company and two men at the centre of the winebox tax inquiry. The Deputy Prime Minister and Treasurer, Winston Peters, said on Wednesday night that the $4 million had not been paid to ATN and would not be until the cabinet was satisfied about the company.

Macraes Mining has reported on unaudited pre-tax profit of $23 million for the 1996 calendar year, nearly doubling the previous year's figure. The result, which the company said on Wednesday would be confirmed by audit next month, sent Macraes's share price soaring 24c before it pulled back to finish the day four cents higher at 29c. The forecast for 1997 is for production of 120,000 to 130,000oz of gold at a cash cost of $450 an oz and a gold price of $685 an oz.

Telecom is cutting 122 staff immediately from its Australian subsidiary Pacific Star Communications as part of a previously announced exit from the loss-making Pacific Star business. The assets of Pacific Star Communications are to be sold. Telecom owns 51 percent of Pacific Star Communications, and Bell Atlantic, a major Telecom shareholder, the other 49 percent.

An estimate by United States invetment bank Goldman Sachs that the New Zealand dollar is 15 percent overvalued had little impact on the kiwi yesterday. It fell 32 points to a six-month low of 68.68 US cents but a lack of buyers, rather than keen

selling, was the reason. But dealers remained wary of more selling of the kiwi overnight in the United States. "They've been quite keen sellers in the last few days and the Goldman report might see that continue," said one.

Just Jeans' 33.5c a share bid for Underground Fashions has been recommended to the New Zealand retailer's 350 minority shareholders by the sole independent director. Stuart Cairns said the offer represented an 88 percent premium over net tangible assets of 17.8c a share estimated for 31.

Directors of music radio station owner Energy Enterprises have recommended shareholders accept a friendly $7.3 million takeover from Radio Pacific. Radio Pacific is offering six of its shares for every five Energy Enterprises shares or an alternative of 360c of cash. At Wednesday's close of 315c for Radio Pacific shares, the offer values Energy shares at 378c.
